title: Only bad super funds fear performance disclosure
text:
APRA has been under pressure to prove it is getting tough on dud funds following criticism by the Graeme Samuel-led capability review and banking royal commission.

"We are in the process of finalising all the details of the methodology and measures we will use for the heatmap, and exactly how we will present them," Mrs Rowell said.

"But what I can share with you is that the heatmap will not include a single, overall product level assessment.

"Rather, the heatmap will display performance across a range of metrics in the areas of investments and fees and costs, and provide indicators for trends in sustainability measures."

Some in the industry fear a run on funds APRA marks down.

Retail super funds, along with some smaller industry funds, are worried that their more conservative investment strategies will make them look like they are under-performing when what they are really doing, they claim, is trying to protect the capital of typically older membership bases.

In September, AMP wealth boss Alex Wade said in order to ensure members were fully informed APRA would need to come up with a credible system for reporting risk-adjusted returns.

He urged the regulator to issue guidance about which types of assets should be classified as growth and which as defensive.

“At present, many members rely on fund labels such as ‘balanced’ to inform their judgment, without realising that the underlying risk in these funds can be quite different,” Mr Wade said.

“Some funds classify illiquid investments, such as unlisted property and infrastructure, as defensive.

“In many cases, these investments have performed well, however, due to the fact they can’t be offloaded as quickly as shares or other liquid investments in the event of a downturn, they potentially carry more risk."
description: The superannuation funds that are jittery about upcoming performance report cards are probably worried they'll come in at the "hotter end of the spectrum".
